column1: Sackville was the name of a relatively young Hobbit family. Their name had an association with Baggins in that both contained an element for "bag/sack"; Sackville was a slightly more aristocratic version.J.R.R. Tolkien
column4: Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings
column7: The Lord of the Rings: A Readers Companion
column8: page 762 Tom Shippey argued that this "similarity" also provoked an antonymy: Bag End was used around England as a replacement of French cul-de-sac
column9: "dead end street" - even Tolkiens own aunt Jane Neave lived in a house of that name. Tolkien did not like the Norman conquest of Britain
column10: and made the Bagginses English. The name Sackville

column1: In J.R.R. Tolkiens manuscript of The Hobbit the Sackville-Baggins were called the Allibone Baggins.
column2: p. 691  John D. Rateliff stated that the change to "Sackville" was penciled in about the time the story was being prepared for publication in 1936.  The significance of "Allibone" is unknown although Mr. Rateliff thought it might relate to Alboin
column3: a character in The Lost Road.
